Comment: The RCMP are arresting and detaining them under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and turning them over to Canada Immigration for processing.

There is a very good legal reason why refugee claimants (not asylum seekers which are a completely different class of persons) are not being charged in respect of their entry to Canada.

Under Article 31 of the 1951 Convention on Refugees Canada has undertaken to not prosecute refugee claimants for illegal entry into Canada including any issues of false documents or fraud relating to that entry.

Canada has enacted that exemption into our domestic law as required by the Convention in various iterations of our immigration legislation over the years. Currently that exemption is contained at s. 133 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.

So no charges because the law exempts refugees recognizing that refugees who are fleeing persecution are different from other migrants.

Comment: Having Irish Catholic ancestors, I wanted to share some observations regarding the words FATHER and MOTHER.    My parents were born in America in the early 1900s.  Apparently, the word FATHER was traditionally reserved for priests, whereas the word MOTHER was proper for female parents.

Irish Catholics usually seemed to prefer “dad”, or less often, “da”.  I knew kids who used the word “pop”, but none seemed to be of Irish descent.  Some of my Protestant friends used the word “father” to address their male parent, which seemed weird to me as a child.

My mother and aunts usually used the word “mother” to address their female parents.  Although my mother would have liked me to do the same, times had changed and I insisted on caller her “mom”.  She endured this generational shift, but did make it clear that calling her “ma” or “mummy” would be disrespectful.

Incidentally, during my early childhood, our pastor was called “Monsignor”, which seems to be equivalent to “My Lord”.

Comment: Scott,

Two points:

1. I think you should provide a reference to the book from which you are drawing the quotation. It is "The Undoing Project" which chronicles the partnership of Daniel Kahneman and Amos Tversky who together pioneered research into many aspects of human decision making, perhaps most notably Prospect Theory.

2. It seems unusual to use a citation to K&T's work as a basis for supporting a passive Index Investing strategy which has the Efficient Markets Hypothesis as part of its rationale. K&T's stands in direct opposition to that hypothesis and is the basis upon which much of Behavioral Finance is built. K&T's work demonstrated that there are legitimate behavioural reasons why certain active investing strategies will provide higher than market returns. A number of factors have been clearly identified, some even by Eugene Fama, the originator of the EMH, himself.  Factor investing strategies are a legitimate alternative to index strategies that investors should consider

Comment: Popular election of the chief executive does not determine whether a government is a pure democracy.

In Gallup polls since they started asking in 1944 until this election, only about 20% of the public has supported the current system of awarding all of a state's electoral votes to the presidential candidate who receives the most votes in each separate state (not mentioned in the U.S. Constitution, but later enacted by 48 states) (with about 70% opposed and about 10% undecided).

Support for a national popular vote for President has been strong among Republicans, Democrats, and Independent voters, as well as every demographic group in every state surveyed. In the 41 red, blue, and purple states surveyed, overall support has been in the 67-81% range - in rural, smal, Southern, big states, and other states polled. 

Most Americans think it is wrong that the candidate with the most popular votes can lose. We don't allow this in any other election in our representative republic.

Comment: My mother held my youngest brother back from Kindergarten (he was born one day before the cutoff date). She felt that unlike his older siblings, he was not ready. I don't think that decision hurt him one bit and if he was ever bugged at school for being older or having 'flunked' he would rightfully have said that his mom had made a decision and there was nothing that he could have done about it.

For a different perspective I would add this: I was a special education teacher for 32 years. Most years we had a preponderance of fall birth-dates... a fairly consistent correlation. 

The central message is this: every kid is different. Some are ready at a certain time and others are not. If a child has not spent time in a larger peer group (eg. day care) then it's difficult for any parent to know how their child's abilities compare to those of other kid. Day care providers and ECEs have a better sense of those relative measures/indicators because they see kids interacting in group settings.

Comment: A 'ranked ballot' might also ensure that the end up with the most bland candidates who will accomplish the least.

In Canada we have used forms of 'ranked ballot' or multiple ballot elections for party leaders in the past, even if we haven't used them for general elections.  One key example of what I'm talking about is how Stephen Dion was selected as party leader in 2006.  In the first ballot Michael Ignatieff was easily the most popular candidate with Bob Rae second and Dion a distant 3rd with less than 18% of the vote.  Similar story in the second round of balloting where Dion managed only 20% of the vote and was still a fairly distant 3rd place finisher.

It was only when they got down to the 3rd and 4th round of balloting that people, grudgingly, decided that they would prefer the 'bland' Dion over the more controversial Ignatieff or Rae.

Another potential problem with ranked ballots is seen in Australia where they have reduced elections to a de facto two-party system.

Comment: Your claim is false, alwordman. The government of Canada does not distinguish between religions for the purposes of tax exemptions. (In fact, it's prevented from doing so by the Charter of Rights and Freedoms.) Whether a group is a "cult" or a major religion, it will receive charitable tax exemptions on the basis of criteria laid down by CRA. The criteria are: 

1.   Maintaining the basic requirements of charitable 
status
2.   Devoting resources to charitable activities
3.   Avoiding private foundation designation 
4.   Ensuring that a public benefit is achieved
5.   Restricting political activities
6.   Filing information returns with CRA
7.   Meeting the disbursement quota requirement
8.   Keeping adequate records and books

As you can see, there's nothing there that distinguishes between religions, cults or any other form of belief or non-belief.

Comment: This was done for television ratings, not competitive balance. The league, especially Detroit and the West-coast teams, wanted the first two rounds in the same time zone, or at most one time zone off, so that their fans could watch the road games at regular hours. Detroit (Eastern time zone) didn't want first round games against San Jose (Pacific) which finish at 1:00 am Eastern. The West coast teams don't want first round games in the East that start at 4:00 pm Pacific. With all 16 East conference teams in the same time zone (after Columbus and Detroit switched conferences), the East wouldn't need a division-based playoff, but the West still includes 3 time zones. This is also why Quebec's expansion bid was refused, the league does not want to add an Eastern time zone team to the West conference.
